body_text.text: The first case of COVID-19 was reported in India on 30 th January, thereafter, a 49 nationwide 14-hour voluntary curfew was observed on 22 nd march due to a jump in 50 number of positive cases. This curfew was extended for another 21 more days from 51 25 th March to 14 th April initially. This lockdown resulted in shutting down schools, national and international boundaries. The lockdown period was further extended in 55 many phases till 8 th June 2020 and a lockdown of total 75 days completed with very 56 strict guidelines, and the nation came to a standstill during this period (Singh, 2020). 57 The lockdown in India has been unique and no such event has taken place over the (Clifford, 2020) . The aforementioned studies reveals that there is a unique condition in various 119 countries due to lockdown and the reduced anthropogenic activities have a direct 120 impact on environmental pollution. Thus, there is an urgent need to study the short 121 and long term changes caused by lockdown in our environmental system. To date 122 very few studies have been undertaken to assess the changes in air and water quality 123 during the lockdown period. As the lockdown in India has entered its 4 th phase, the 124 present study was undertaken to study the environmental impacts of COVID-19 in 125 the Ahmadabad Metropolitan city using Landsat 8 OLI sensor data with the 126 objective to understand the short-term changes in water and air quality. 128 We chose the Sabarmati river (Ahmedabad section) as our study area to assess its 129 water quality. This has led to a decline in emissions and restricted the production 60 of industrial waste and other pollutants in the urban centers of India during the 61 duration of lockdown. 62 The anthropogenic activities are known to be one of the primary drivers of 63 pollution within various spheres of the environment (Akimoto, 2003; Volkamer et 64 al., 2006; Masood et al., 2016; Schlacher et al., 2016). Since the lockdown 65 implemented due to COVID-19 in various countries has almost seized the industrial 66 activities and vehicle movement, a decrease in air pollution across the globe has been 67 reported (Henriques, 2020 and Stone, 2020). Several studies has conducted analysis 68 on the short term impact of COVID-19 in the atmospheric column, including the 69 satellite monitoring program from Sentinel 5 mission (ESA, 2020), but studies 70 pertaining to hydrosphere are very few. Hader et al. (2020) have emphasized that the 71 lockdown period has drastically reduced the industrial waste generation, industrial 72 pollution, and the addition of heavy metals and plastic to hydrosphere through 73 different sources. This 81 manual process is not only time consuming and expensive, but also not suitable for 82 analysis over a regional scale (Duan et al., 2013; Ritchie et al., 2003). Recently, remote 83 sensing techniques have been widely used to undertake these studies with accuracy, 84 and advantageous of having both cost and time over the manual approaches (Yunus 85 et al., 2019; Avtar et al., 2019). The use of remotely sensed data helps not only to 86 monitor and identify the water quality over a large regions, but temporal changes 87 can also be assessed regularly. (Dekker et al., 1996; Wang and Ma, 2001; Alparslan et 88 al., 2007; Zhu and Dou, 2018; Ali et al., 2019). The remote sensing based water 89 quality is undertaken by analyzing the spectral characteristics of water color. These 90 spectral characteristics are the function of chemical, hydrological and biological 91 characteristics of water (Wang and Yang, 2019).

FIGREF4.text: In this study we considered turbidity of water as a criterion of water pollution 93(Stumpf and Pennock, 1989). A higher levels of suspended particulate matter (SPM)94 caused by sedimentation, sewage disposals, and other pollutants results in a high 95 level of turbidity (Yunus et al., 2020). The remote sensing techniques have analyzed 96 J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f the relationship between turbidity and reflectance in water bodies (Curran et al., 97 1987; Novo et al., 1989; Sravanthi et al., 2013). It was observed that an increase in 98 turbidity leads to an increase in reflectance levels in water bodies (Doxaran et al., 99 2002). Thus, empirically calibrated models, machine learning and artificial 100 intelligence etc. have been developed to fit the reflectance spectrum with in-situ 101 profiles (Doxaran et al., 2002, Yunus et al., 2019; Davies-Colley and Smith, 2001; Luis 102 et al., 2019). Among these, machine learning has becoming popular recently in many 103 fields of satellite remote sensing and GIS analysis (Dou et al., 2020; Merghadi et al., 104 2020). Over the years, various satellite sensors have been widely used by scholars to 105 map the SPM in aquatic systems. These includes Sentinal-2, Landsat series, Spot 106 series, MODIS Aqua and Terra, SeaWiFS and OceanSAT, etc. (Vanhellemont and 107 Ruddick, 2014; Gholizadeh et al., 2016; Wei et al., 2018).

FIGREF11.text: 4 demonstrates the SPM concentration in the Sabarmati river; qualitative 184 analysis suggest a decrease in the overall SPM levels during the lockdown period 185 when compared to pre-lockdown period and previous years. Quantitative values of 186 SPM are depicted inTable 2; the SPM concentration ranges observed during the 187 lockdown period was 4.55 mg/l -10.79 mg/l and the average SPM was found to be188 8.08 mg/l . The results show that the maximum SPM concentration for April in the 189 last five years was observed in April 2015 (14.73 mg/l), whereas the minimum values 190 (6.65 mg/l) were observed in April 2017. Thus, the average SPM concentration for 191 April 2020 (lockdown period) is second lowest in the last six years and the lowest 192 value was found for April 2017.193 To analyze the impact of lockdown on the river water quality, the SPM 194 concentrations for the pre-lockdown period was also analyzed for the duration of 195 about one month and it varied from 4.96 mg/l to 19.34 mg/l and the average for pre 196 lockdown period was estimated to be 12.72 mg/l. The analysis of SPM during the 197 lockdown was undertaken for five different days starting from 3 rd April to 14 th May 198 and a gradual decline with time in SPM concentrations is observed from 10.85 mg/l 199 to 5.01 mg/l with a single upsurge on 5th May. The average SPM concentration for 200 the lockdown period was calculated to be 8.08 mg/l, which is significantly lower 201 than the pre-lockdown period average (12.72 mg/l), as well as the previous year 202 average (9.71 mg/l). This suggests a substantial decrease of 36.48% in SPM 203 concentrations during the lockdown period as compared with the pre-lockdown the closure of anthropogenic and industrial activities has resulted in the 207 decline of SPM concentration in the Sabarmati river. The upsurge in SPM 208 concentration observed on 5 th May 2020 may be supported by the fact that the 209 natural river sedimentation can also alter the SPM levels in water bodies. The flow of 210 sediments is governed by many factors such as precipitation, water and soil 211 conservation projects, construction of reservoirs, carbonate weathering, dilution, etc. Kumar et al., 2015; Liu et al., 2019). The upstream of Sabarmati experienced 213 precipitation in early May 2020 (TOI, 2020) and that can be the possible source of 214 high SPM concentrations on 5 th May 2020.215

A sharp decrease in PM2.5 was observed at the 229 beginning of lockdown i.e. after 24 th April 2020(Fig.5a). Other parameters such as 230 NO2 and PM10 concentrations also found to be much lower than the pre-lockdown231 period, and NO2 concentrations in April 2020 are the minimum in the last three years 232 (Fig. 5b) with no excessive variations observed. The NO2 and PM10 values in April 233 2020 well were within the prescribed limit, which is 40 µg/m 3 for NO2 and 60 µg/m 3 234 for PM10, set by CPCB, India. The results concur with the recent studies by Mahato et 235 al. (2020), Sharma et al. (2020), and Gautam (2020) evaluating improved air quality in 236 different cities of India, and also worldwide (Tobias et al., 2020; Dantas et al., 2020; 237 Isaifan, 2020 and Zambrano-Monserrate et al., 2020).2385. Conclusion239The COVID-19 is a severe threat to human life and more than 500,000 deaths have240 been reported worldwide (as on 9 th July 2020). However, with the complete 241 restrictions on economic, social, educational, religious, and all other activities, this 242 lockdown is turning into a "Blessing in disguise" (Muhammad et al., 2020). The 243 authors attempted to analyze whether these restrictions have their impact on one of 244 the severely polluted west-flowing rivers in India. The analysis revealed that the 245 SPM concentrations in the Sabarmati river have reduced to a great extent. The 246 changes pre and during lockdown are very significant to understand the short-term, 247 as well as the long-term effect of anthropogenic activities on the hydrosphere. An 248 average decrease of 36.48% is observed in SPM concentrations during lockdown 249 compared to the pre-lockdown period albeit the domestic wastewater continues to 250 drain into the Sabarmati river and which eventually shows the degree to which the 251 industrial sewage discharge and other outdoor activities are deteriorating the 252 hydrosphere and severely polluting the river water. The effect of lockdown is also 253 clear on the air quality, as all the main parameters (NO2, PM2.5, and PM10) have decreased to a noticeable extent from the pre-lockdown period and NO2 255 concentrations are found to be minimum in last three years. However all these 256 human activities will resume sooner or later, and since the Sabarmati river is 257 surrounded by dense urban population, the pollutants may ultimately start 258 deteriorating the water and air quality again and the improvement reaped during 259 lockdown won't continue for long. Therefore, the Policymakers should take note of 260 these improved air and water quality conditions due to the ceased anthropogenic 261 activities and should plan the future urban dynamics accordingly.
